Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Eco-friendly Thermal Insulation Composite Foam Boards
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I project will develop a novel, environmentally-friendly thermal insulation composite foam board. The environmental and economic impacts of energy production and use are key areas of concern in the world today. One of the largest uses of energy is for heating and cooling of buildings; thus construction companies are always searching for products which can improve the insulation performance of buildings. The rigid foam board insulation products in widespread use today are produced from petroleum-based chemicals. The availability of insulation which supports green building initiatives will be a great boon to eco-conscious customers, and will provide an excellent incentive for others to use the foam board product. The foam board is the first of a number of envisioned products which will leverage cellulose nanofibrils (CNFs), which have been long-studied but are now on the verge of becoming available in sufficient quantities to realize their potential in commercial products. Successful conclusion of this effort will demonstrate a unique, innovative product that will have excellent mechanical and thermal properties at comparable prices to incumbent petroleum-based materials.

The intellectual merit of this project is to determine the feasibility of creating a CNF-reinforced corn starch foam to produce an eco-friendly thermal insulation foam board for use in the construction industry. The raw material, cellulose, is an abundant material, obtainable from renewable sources including a broad range of plants and sea animals (tunicates). CNFs have a significant ability to reinforce otherwise weak materials, permitting new composite products with extremely beneficial characteristics. Corn starch, a readily available renewable resource, has many important industrial uses in films, foams, and aerogels, but on its own is weak and brittle. The project objectives are to create the first corn starch based foam board with the desired material properties of low density, high mechanical properties, fire retardancy, water repellency and low thermal conductivity. The team will explore various materials combinations and chemical treatments to produce foam boards that have the material properties required to meet market needs. The foam board will have comparable or better mechanical and thermal properties to typical petroleum-based polystyrene foam boards on the market, but with a dramatically lower carbon footprint.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Under this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) Phase I/IB Project (Award No. 1521326), Revolution Research Inc. (RRI) developed process technologies to create a bio-based, environmentally friendly, lightweight, fireproof, water repellent foam board. Arbolate™ was developed for use as rigid thermal insulation in residential or commercial structures.

Arbolate’s primary ingredient is nanocellulose, a material consisting of minute fibers derived from wood. RRI uses a form of nanocellulose called cellulose nanofibrils (CNF) and other natural materials together with an innovative processing technology to create the product. Arbolate is biodegradable, recyclable, sustainable, and non-toxic. It has insulation properties (R-values) comparable to currently marketed rigid insulation products, and can be safely and easily cut to size. Unlike some other products labeled as “green” because they contain a small percentage of recycled material, Arbolate is truly “green” from its sustainably-sourced content, through its manufacturing process, and finally for its end-of-useful life options.

The rigid foam insulation board market is currently dominated by the petroleum-based, styrene products that are not biodegradable or recyclable. These products are typically composed of expanded polystyrene (EPS) or extruded polystyrene (XPS), which are flammable, potentially hazardous, and not biodegradable or recyclable. Because polystyrene does not break down in the environment, it is an abundant form of litter and its light weight make it easily transported by wind and water. The presence of polystyrene waste is not only an eyesore and nuisance, but birds, small animals, and marine wildlife are known to ingest small pieces, causing health problems.  

Corporations and consumers are becoming increasingly concerned with the impacts of their buying decisions on the environment and their health and welfare. Green building products is a growing market and RRI’s market investigations showed that customers would likely be interested in a bio-based rigid insulation and would be willing to pay up to 20% more for it. Arbolate will fill this niche for a truly green foam board that reduces the use of petroleum-based chemicals, supports a cleaner environment by being bio-based, is a zero-landfill product, and provides good insulation (minimum R 3.2 per inch of thickness). RRI has submitted two provisional patent applications for this product and technology.

In addition to the inherent benefits of an eco-friendly alternative to polystyrene-based rigid insulation products, RRI’s work will serve as the foundation for developing other nanocellulose-based products to replace unsustainable, petroleum-based foam boards and panels used in arts and crafts, signage, packaging, food containers, and other building products. Commercializing new nanocellulose-based products will also stimulate the nation’s forest product industry, which has declined in recent years due to the closing of many paper mills. Located primarily in rural areas, their closing has severely impacted the regional economy and developing new forest-based products will serve to return jobs and improve overall socioeconomic conditions.
